bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, December 30, 1900

div1.p: Reed writes about Emilie Lawrence Reed's recovery, as well as his toothache. He discusses financial matters, including expenditures at Keewaydin. His last yellow fever patient is recovering.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, December 30, 1900
div1.p:
What
a dear, sweet Christmas
letter came, yesterday, from
the dearest woman in
all the world! It did make
me so happy to know that
you, like a sweet, sensible,
woman, were enjoying
yourself in a quiet, peace-
ful way, with the bird,
& the flowers & the cat, al-
though everybody was away
from home, including even
fat little scholar! You
were right, my joy, in stop-
ping
at the market to buy you
some pretty flowers for your
darling room- I know that
the latter, under your deft
fingers, looked beautiful
and inviting. I wish that
I could have peeped in
upon my sweet Miss Gouty
and her companions! What
will you do, sweetheart,
when I come back & in-
trude myself and my “traps”
into your quiet habitation?
I am very much afraid that
my darling wifie will be
too much crowded and made
very uncomfortable- I will
try, however, to make myself
“small” and not take up too
much room. If I get in
the way, you must tell
me so, and I promise to do
whatever you say! Dear
aunt Jane, I was so sorry
to hear that she was sick,
and trust that it is only a
slight indisposition of the
“liver”! Do pray, give her much
love for me when you
write to her. Isn't it simply
lovely that you, my precious
joy, can jet about so well
again, after so much lame-
ness! Did you really walk
to Lafayette Square and return?
That was too far, sweet-
heart! You should have
ridden back- I can sympa-
thize with you, sweetheart,
for I have had two horrid,
growling, grumbling, painful
C1
B9
teeth that have made me
so mad & disgusted during
these last 3 or 4 days that I
could hardly do any thing -- one
of them is that horrid, nasty
lower incisor tooth that I have
been nursing for these last
five years- I shan't be in
Washington one day before
I will have it “yanked
out” nolens, rolens! You
know how very trying, lovie, dear,
that continual aching becomes,
after it has kept up for
half a week! I may have
both of the “growlers” extracted
before many days go by-
Is there any thing so trying to one's
disposition as an everlasting,
never-ceasing pain? How my
precious wife must enjoy
being rid of hers! Am so glad
that auntie and the girls re-
membered you with some-
thing for your room- So you
really haven't had much of
a winter yet? I do hope,
for the sake of all people who
dislike cold weather, that this
winter will be a mild one.
December here has been much
warmer than November was.
A temperature of 85° is quite
an ordinary one, these latter
days. To-day, a hot southern
wind has blown all day.
So Johnnie Moore has sent
in his last checkbill for 1900?
Well, I, too, am very glad of
it- Next year he will have
to rest satisfied with less
of an income.
I find, upon looking over my
book of expenses, that we have
expended on our dear Keewaydin,
during 1900, the sum of $963.72
of this amount $212.00 was a
second payment on the land
purchased from Wastler- So that
we really expended on im-
provements during the year
just $751.72 -- of this sum, we
paid to Johnnie Moore for labor
on house, stone fences, wood-
land & C $434.68- I find that
to clear up that rear lot cost
two hundred and seventeen
dollars & eight cents ($217.08).
Well, there is one satisfac-
tion, lovie, dear, it won't have
to be cleared again! Aside
from our house, we won't
have to expend much for im-
provements here after- I think
that one hundred or one hun-
dred & fifty dollars should cover
expenses, the coming year, if
we don't build our stable.
I don't however begrude any
money spent on our little home
since I know how much pleas-
ure my sweet wifie has ex-
tracted out of the days spent
there. If our precious little
daughter would learn to
love it as you and I do, then
I should feel that there was
no such sweet home in
all the world! Never mind,
I shall hope to see her busy
digging in her flower-bed
next year- I am quite sure
that my sweet wifie will not
fail to dig daily in her beds!
And such flowers as she will have!

Monday morning. Dec. 31, 1900-
Good-morning my precious wifie
and good morning, my dear little
Annapolis Visitor! How are my
precious girls on this the last
day of the year and of the
Century? Papa hopes that they
are both well & happy and
thinking of him- Dear Me! Papa
forgot that it wasis not yet
seven o'clock & that his joys
snooze & snooze long after that
hour! I guess the precious dears
have just turned over for another
hour's nap! Our last case, lovie
dear, has no fever this morning
& is therefore practically convales-
cent. He has been quite sick-
Get up! Get up! and be smart
girls for the new century! May
the new year bring to my precious
darlings much happiness and
no gout! Love & kisses for my sweet,
sweet girls,
